subject: Re: [junit] Question on assertEquals()
msgSnippet: ... No, you don t. All implementations of List, Set and Map provide equals() that does the right thing. You have to be sure the objects you put in those
messageBody:
Tiago Fernandez wrote:
> I guess that's because JUnit doesn't have assertion methods taking
> Set/Collection/Object[] as parameters. You have to perform an assertion for
> both Set's sizes, sort them, make a loop and compare each element. Something
> like this...

No, you don't. All implementations of List, Set and Map provide equals()
that does the right thing. You have to be sure the objects you put in
those collections implement equals() and hashCode() correctly.
--
